channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Capital Account: As global fertility rates drop, two economists make the case for humans
item.description: As global fertility rates drop, two economists make the case for humans.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Beijing Pivots to Rein In Excess Capacity Amid Squeezed Industrial Profit
item.description: In the latest sign of stress facing Chinese companies, official data released Sunday showed China’s industrial profit declined 1.8% from a year earlier in the first half of the year.

item.title: Now that President Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill Act is law, the fight has begun over who wins and who loses from its tax-and-spending changes
item.description: Was it the lowest, middle or highest income taxpayers? See where you fall.
item.dc:creator: Kara Dapena

item.title: Ratings agency Moody’s boosted Turkey’s credit ratings, citing stabilizing and disinflationary central bank policy
item.description: The ratings agency said Friday it lifted the country’s long-term foreign currency sovereign-credit ratings and local currency issuer ratings to Ba3 from B1.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas G. Miller

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Fed Decision, U.S. Jobs Data, Tariff Deadline in Focus
item.description: A U.S. Federal Reserve interest-rate decision; President Trump’s August 1 deadline for reciprocal tariffs; and key data on U.S. jobs, economic growth and inflation will take center stage in a busy week for markets.
item.dc:creator: Dow Jones Newswires staff

item.title: U.S. Durable Goods Orders Sink on Lower Aircraft Orders
item.description: Total orders for goods made to last at least three years, such as automobiles, planes and electronic equipment, were 9.3% lower in June than in May, Commerce Department data said Friday. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected an 11.1% slump.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: ECB Must Remain Completely Open in Future Rate Decisions, Says Villeroy
item.description: Policymakers must remain agile, noting that the stronger euro was having a significant disinflationary effect, Bank of France Governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Russia’s Central Bank Cuts Key Rate Again as Economy Slows
item.description: Friday marked the second-straight time the Bank of Russia cut its interest rate after it lowered borrowing costs in early June.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: German Business Sentiment Edges Higher Despite Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: The increase was a sign of resilience against U.S. tariffs, though uncertainty kept any upswing in check.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: U.K. Retailers Get Summer Boost as Drinks Sales Soar
item.description: Retail sales were 0.9% higher on month in June, with alcoholic and nonalcoholic drinks among the products which saw higher sales.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Who is shouldering the burden of Trump’s tariffs? So far, it’s corporate America, but for how long?
item.description: Neither consumers nor foreign countries are assuming much of the tariff burden. At least not yet.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Nassauer

item.title: As the U.S. heads toward trade talks with China next week, President Trump is increasingly focused on trying to strike an economic bargain with Beijing
item.description: The White House puts a priority on doing business with Beijing as it prepares for bilateral talks next week.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: U.K. Consumers Are Feeling Gloomier Amid Foundering Economy, Rising Prices
item.description: U.K. consumer sentiment worsened as the country faces an unhappy combination of weak growth and still-high inflation.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Streetwise: The Trump administration has ramped up its attacks on Fed Chairman Jerome Powell. The louder he shouts, the less likely he is to get what he really wants: lower borrowing costs.
item.description: If the president thinks the Fed is hard to deal with, wait until he tries to negotiate with the bond market.
item.dc:creator: James Mackintosh

item.title: President Trump turned a rare visit to the Federal Reserve into political theater that included hard hats and a back slap
item.description: The president turned a rare visit to the U.S. central bank into political theater that included hard hats and a back slap.
item.dc:creator: Meridith McGraw

item.title: The yearslong project to overhaul the Federal Reserve buildings in D.C. has run into multiple hurdles, including higher-than-expected groundwater at the site
item.description: The yearslong project to overhaul the U.S. central bank’s headquarters in Washington, D.C., has run into multiple hurdles, including higher-than-expected groundwater at the site.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Global Economies Show Resilience Despite Tariff Fears, Surveys Show
item.description: The U.S. economy and its peers in Europe and Asia continued to show resilience in the face of high levels of uncertainty about the future of trade and international relations, although export orders weakened.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Fewer U.S. Jobless Claims Were Filed Last Week
item.description: U.S. initial jobless claims declined last week, according to the Department of Labor, extending a stretch of evidence that layoffs have remained constrained.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: German Consumer Confidence Hit by Economic Uncertainty
item.description: Sentiment continued to worsen as growing economic uncertainty encouraged shoppers to save rather than spend, according to a monthly survey.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Asia-U.S. Trade Deals Pick Up as Tariff Deadline Nears
item.description: Excluding a truce with China, four Asian nations have now reached deals, with just over a week before the grace period expires.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Lee

item.title: President Trump’s push to introduce a new standard for global trade is coming into sharper focus as U.S. and EU officials converge on a possible 15% tariff deal
item.description: A deal with Japan and a potential deal with Europe follow months of uncertainty and will likely raise prices while offering a bit of clarity for global trade.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: Eurozone Consumers’ Mood Improves a Little
item.description: Consumers in the eurozone are a little less gloomy as inflation stabilizes, despite global economic uncertainty, a recent monthly survey showed.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Home prices rose to a new high in June while the crucial spring sales season fizzled
item.description: The key spring-selling season failed to deliver, making a housing-market recovery unlikely this year.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: President Trump announced a trade deal with Japan, saying the country will face 15% reciprocal tariffs
item.description: President Trump says Tokyo will face 15% reciprocal tariffs instead of the 25% he had threatened while the nation invests $550 billion into the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: A bill unveiled Friday aims to provide government backing for second mortgages to finance construction of increasingly popular accessory dwelling units
item.description: A bill unveiled Friday aims to provide government backing for second mortgages to finance construction of increasingly popular accessory dwelling units.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Home-building recovered a little in the U.S. last month but remains down on the year.
item.description: Home-building recovered a little in the U.S. last month but tariffs continued to cause uncertainty in the sector.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The number of Americans who newly filed for unemployment benefits declined to 221,000 last week, the Labor Department said.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Climb in Australian Jobless Rate Opens Door to Rate Cut
item.description: Australia’s unemployment rate rose unexpectedly in June, significantly boosting the case for an interest-rate cut in August.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: Leading Economies Must Work Together to Fix Imbalances, or Face Instability, Says BOE’s Bailey
item.description: The U.S., China and other leading economies should work together to agree on a set of national policies that will help narrow the large imbalances that now threaten the global trade system, the Bank of England governor said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Economy Unexpectedly Slumps to Second Straight Month of Contraction
item.description: The economy contracted in May, a sharp reversal in fortune that makes it more likely the BOE will cut its key interest rate soon.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The number of Americans who newly filed for unemployment benefits declined last week, the Labor Department said, although the report suggested that the size of the unemployed population continued to grow in June.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Without Remedy, Countries With Aging Populations Are Set for Weaker Income Growth, Says OECD
item.description: Incomes in rich countries are going to grow much more slowly as populations age unless more women, older people and migrants can be persuaded to work, the OECD said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: The number of first-time home buyers is dwindling, and they are handing a win to landlords
item.description: America’s renter population has hit a record because fewer people can afford to get on the housing ladder.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Mortgage rates holding stubbornly above 6.6% leave many people stuck with higher monthly costs and no path to refinance
item.description: Mortgage rates holding stubbornly above 6.6% leave many people stuck with higher monthly costs and no path to refinance
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: U.S. job growth looked solid in June, but the headline number hides a stark reality: Many private employers aren’t hiring anymore.
item.description: The U.S. economy added 147,000 jobs in June, but nearly half were in government.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Weber

item.title: The Conference Board’s June consumer-confidence index fell to 93, from 98.4 in May, surprising analysts
item.description: U.S. consumer confidence slipped in June, reversing an improvement in May, according to the Conference Board.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman
